title: Ticket #3847: Freezer controller triggers kernel crash when freezing SIGSTOP'd proce
description:
While we can't reproduce the exact conditions, it seems HTCondor triggers a kernel crash when:
  • A job has already been suspended (likely, when any processes in the job are suspended).
  • The freezer controller is used to freeze the set of processes.

While the freezer controller provides atomic signal delivery to jobs - very important for killing jobs - it's probably more important to not trigger a kernel crash. Proposal: have the procd track whether the process family is currently suspended; if it is, don't use the freezer-based methods for signal delivery.

This has a slight security risk - we re-introduce the possibility of a fork-bomb escaping signal delivery. I believe this is acceptable because:

  • We can track which processes still exist post-SIGTERM, and
  • if the freezer did the SIGSTOP, we can assume all processes are already stopped - there's nothing alive to forkbomb.
remarks:
2013-Aug-12 10:22:03 by bbockelm:
To test -

  • Turn procd log on and on D_FULLDEBUG
  • Submit a simple "condor_run sleep 1h" job. Wait for it to start running.
  • Suspend job with condor_suspend.
  • Hold job.
  • Look at procd log; verify that there is a log statement that the freezer controller was not used.

Repeat this without the condor_suspend step; verify there is a log statement that the freezer controller was used after the hold.
